block.p: Rachel Rebecca Nussbaum, the daughter of Neda Nussbaum and Dr. Alan Nussbaum of Charleston, S.C., is to be married there today to Noam F. Pianko, a son of Rina and Howard Pianko of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Chezi Zionce is to officiate at congregation Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim.

The bride, 26, who will continue to use her name, is a fifth-year rabbinical student at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in New York. She graduated summa cum laude from Duke. Her father is a partner in Rheumatology Associates in Charleston and her mother manages the practice. Dr. Nussbaum is the president of the Medical Society of South Carolina.
Rachel Rebecca Nussbaum is to be married Sunday to Noam F. Pianko at congregation Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim in Charleston, S.C.

Rachel Rebecca Nussbaum, the daughter of Neda Nussbaum and Dr. Alan Nussbaum of Charleston, S.C., is to be married there today to Noam F. Pianko, a son of Rina and Howard Pianko of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Chezi Zionce is to officiate at congregation Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim.

The bride, 26, who will continue to use her name, is a fifth-year rabbinical student at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in New York. She graduated summa cum laude from Duke. Her father is a partner in Rheumatology Associates in Charleston and her mother manages the practice. Dr. Nussbaum is the president of the Medical Society of South Carolina.

The bridegroom, 30, is a candidate for a doctorate in Jewish history at Yale. He graduated magna cum laude from Brown. His mother is a board member of Project Ezra, a nonprofit organization supporting Jewish elderly on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. His father is a partner in the Manhattan office of Epstein Becker & Green.
